anchor.surface_text: under section 10 ? The matter relates to the assessment year 1956-57. The appellant is a private limited companypany and Kailash Nath Agarwal is one of its directors. issues.text: Whether on the facts and on a true and proper interpretation of the agreement dated 31-7-1956, between the British India Corporation and the appellant company, the letters of Sri Kailash Nath Agarwal, the letters of Managing Directors, the sum of Rs. 43,333/ retained by the British India Corporation and adjusted by it to the credit of Sharma Co. was the assessable income of the appellant company ?

issues.text: whether the money paid is a revenue-expenditure or capital expenditure

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question as to whether the money paid is a revenue-expenditure or capital expenditure depends not so much upon the fact as to whether the amount paid is large or small or whether it has been paid in lump sum or by instalments, as it does upon the purpose for which the payment has been made and expenditure incurred.

arguments.claim: The appellant got the sole selling agency in consideration of agreeing to pay the dues of Sharma Co. to BIC

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the resume of facts given above that in March 1955 an amount of Rs. 8,39,350/15/6 was due to BIC from the firm Sharma Co. who was the previous sole selling agent of the Kanpur Cotton Mills. As a result of agreement between the appellant, BIC and Sharma Co. the appellant undertook to discharge the liability of Sharma Co. in lieu of being appointed the sole selling agent of the Kanpur Cotton Mills, in place of Sharma Co. It can, therefore, be said that 1082 the appellant got the sole selling agency of the Kanpur Cotton Mills in companysideration of its agreeing to pay Rs. 8,39,350-15-6 which was the amount due from Sharma Co. to BIC.

arguments.claim: Payment in lump sum would constitute capital expenditure and payment in instalments makes no difference

anchor.surface_text: companystituted capital expenditure as it was an amount paid for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business. The fact that the amount was paid number in lump sum but was paid in instalments through deductions out of the companymission due to the appellant would number, in our opinion, make any difference.

arguments.claim: Character of expenditure depends on purpose for which payment made, not on quantum, manner, source or periodicity

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question as to whether the money paid is a revenue-expenditure or capital expenditure depends number so much upon the fact as to whether the amount paid is large or small or whether it has been paid in lump sum or by instalments, as it does upon the purpose for which the payment has been made and expenditure incurred. It is the real nature and quality of the payment and number the quantum or the manner of the payment which would prove decisive.

arguments.claim: Expenditure for acquiring enduring benefit is capital; for running business to produce profits is revenue

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court, in the case of Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal 1 , if the expenditure is made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business it is properly attributable to capital and is of the nature of capital expenditure. If on the other hand it is made number for the purpose of bringing into existence any such asset of advantage but for running the business or working it with a view to produce the profits it is a revenue expenditure.

arguments.claim: Large amount or periodicity has no decisive bearing; name may indicate but true nature determines

anchor.surface_text: It may also be stated as a general rule that the fact that the amount involved was large or that it was periodic in character have numberdecisive bearing upon the matter. A payment may even be described as pay remuneration, etc., but that does number determine its quality, though the name by which it has been called may be relevant in determining its true nature, because this gives an indication of how the person who paid the money and the person who received it viewed it in the first instance.

arguments.claim: The amount was deducted in pursuance of agreement to pay in consideration of being appointed sole selling agent

anchor.surface_text: The amount was deducted by BIC in pursuance of the agreement entered into by the appellant with BIC and Sharma Co., according to which the appellant had to pay that amount in the form of deduction out of its companymission in companysideration of being appointed the sole selling agent of the Kanpur Cotton Mills.

arguments.claim: Liability undertaken for acquiring sole selling agency right, an asset of capital nature

anchor.surface_text: The present is a case relating to the application of income to discharge a liability incurred number in the companyrse of running the business but a liability undertaken for the purpose of acquiring the sole selling agency right which was indisputably an asset of capital nature.

holdings.text: There is, in our opinion, no force in this contention and we agree with Mr. Ram Chandran, learned counsel for the respondent, that the judgment of the High Court should be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion, no force in this contention and we agree with Mr. Ram Chandran, learned counsel for the respondent, that the judgment of the High Court should be, ,upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects appellant's claim for deduction and affirms High Court's answers to referred questions.

holdings.text: As a result of agreement between the appellant, BIC and Sharma Co. the appellant undertook to discharge the liability of Sharma Co. in lieu of being appointed the sole selling agent of the Kanpur Cotton Mills, in place of Sharma Co. It can, therefore, be said that the appellant got the sole selling agency of the Kanpur Cotton Mills in consideration of its agreeing to pay Rs. 8,39,350-15-6 which was the amount due from Sharma Co. to BIC.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the resume of facts given above that in March 1955 an amount of Rs. 8,39,350/15/6 was due to BIC from the firm Sharma Co. who was the previous sole selling agent of the Kanpur Cotton Mills. As a result of agreement between the appellant, BIC and Sharma Co. the appellant undertook to discharge the liability of Sharma Co. in lieu of being appointed the sole selling agent of the Kanpur Cotton Mills, in place of Sharma Co. It can, therefore, be said that 1082 the appellant got the sole selling agency of the Kanpur Cotton Mills in companysideration of its agreeing to pay Rs. 8,39,350-15-6 which was the amount due from Sharma Co. to BIC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretation of agreements shows appellant's appointment as agent was in exchange for assuming Sharma Co.'s debt.

holdings.text: the payment would have constituted capital expenditure as it was an amount paid for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business. The fact that the amount was paid not in lump sum but was paid in instalments through deductions out of the commission due to the appellant would not, in our opinion, make any difference.

anchor.surface_text: companystituted capital expenditure as it was an amount paid for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business. The fact that the amount was paid number in lump sum but was paid in instalments through deductions out of the companymission due to the appellant would number, in our opinion, make any difference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lump sum or instalments irrelevant; payment secures enduring agency benefit, hence capital.

holdings.text: The answer to the question as to whether the money paid is a revenue-expenditure or capital expenditure depends not so much upon the fact as to whether the amount paid is large or small or whether it has been paid in lump sum or by instalments, as it does upon the purpose for which the payment has been made and expenditure incurred. It is the real nature and quality of the payment and not the quantum or the manner of the payment which would prove decisive.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question as to whether the money paid is a revenue-expenditure or capital expenditure depends number so much upon the fact as to whether the amount paid is large or small or whether it has been paid in lump sum or by instalments, as it does upon the purpose for which the payment has been made and expenditure incurred. It is the real nature and quality of the payment and number the quantum or the manner of the payment which would prove decisive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose of payment determines capital or revenue character, overriding factors like amount, form, or frequency.

holdings.text: if the expenditure is made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business it is properly attributable to capital and is of the nature of capital expenditure. If on the other hand it is made not for the purpose of bringing into existence any such asset or advantage but for running the business or working it with a view to produce the profits it is a revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court, in the case of Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal 1 , if the expenditure is made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business it is properly attributable to capital and is of the nature of capital expenditure. If on the other hand it is made number for the purpose of bringing into existence any such asset of advantage but for running the business or working it with a view to produce the profits it is a revenue expenditure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Supreme Court precedent distinguishing capital (enduring benefit) from revenue (business operations) expenditure.

precedents.citation: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal 1

precedents.case_name: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: If the expenditure is made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business it is properly attributable to capital and is of the nature of capital expenditure. If on the other hand it is made not for the purpose of bringing into existence any such asset or advantage but for running the business or working it with a view to produce the profits it is a revenue expenditure. The aim and object of the expenditure would determine the character of the expenditure.

precedents.citation: P. H. Divecha  Deceased  and After Him His Legal Representatives and Another v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City 1 2 .  1  1955 27 I.T.R. 34  on p. 45 .  2  1963 48 I.T.R. 222

precedents.cited_proposition: It may also be stated as a general rule that the fact that the amount involved was large or that it was periodic in character have no decisive bearing upon the matter. A payment may even be described as pay remuneration, etc., but that does not determine its quality... The periodicity of the payment does not make the payment a recurring income because periodicity may be the result of convenience and not necessarily the result of the establishment of a source expected to be productive over a certain period.
